PublisherName.String: Department of Epidemiology and Public Health, University College London

Abstract.Content: The Whitehall II study was established in 1985 to investigate the causes of social inequalities in health. Since this first wave of data collection, self-completion questionnaires and clinical data have been collected from the cohort every two to five years with a high level of participation. The study has shown the importance of psychosocial factors such as work stress and work-family conflict in heart disease and diabetes. These are in addition to the contribution of unhealthy behaviours and traditional risk factors (such as high blood pressure). By combining over 30 years of data on social inequalities and chronic disease with new clinical measures of cognitive function, mental disorders and physical functioning, the Whitehall II study has become a world-class, interdisciplinary study of ageing, allowing research on multi-morbidity, functional decline, frailty, disability, and dementia. Study website: http://www.ucl.ac.uk/whitehallII
First collection of self-reported questionnaire data and biomedical measurements from the totality of Whitehall II cohort members.
Second collection of self-reported questionnaire data from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
Third collection of self-reported questionnaire data and biomedical measurements from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
Fourth collection of self-reported questionnaire data from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
Fifth collection of self-reported questionnaire data and biomedical measurements from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
Sixth collection of self-reported questionnaire data from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
Seventh collection of self-reported questionnaire data and biomedical measurements from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
Eighth collection of self-reported questionnaire data from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
Ninth collection of self-reported questionnaire data and biomedical measurements from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
The tenth collection of data was a pilot carried out on a small group of Whitehall II participants to test new measures for mental well-being introduced at Phase 11.
Eleventh collection of self-reported questionnaire data and biomedical measurements from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.

Description.Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

Abstract.Content: Twelfth collection of self-reported questionnaire data and biomedical measurements from the eligible Whitehall II cohort members.
